name: nytimes
text: When India locked down with four hours notice in March, tens of millions of migrant workers were left stranded. The situation became so dire that the government eventually set up trains to get them home ‚Äî and sent the virus deep into the country's villages.https://t.co/dNwHwkQ6Lz https://t.co/av1kXHIwbs

name: nytimes
text: India has now reported more cases than any country beside the U.S. And it's become clear that the government's trai‚Ä¶ https://t.co/Opm7XEGKtV

name: nytimes
text: Just how disastrous was the lack of planning? Prime Minister Modi's Covid-19 task force, dominated by upper-caste H‚Ä¶ https://t.co/DerCC1V8CC

name: nytimes
text: Modi‚Äôs lockdown closed public transport, so migrants, stranded without food or work, began walking hundreds of mile‚Ä¶ https://t.co/H5iN2A8LPY

name: nytimes
text: Railroad officials concluded they had to step in. But few people were tested before boarding. Social distancing was nonexistent. The trains became contagion zones, and the impact on the villages they arrived in was devastating. https://t.co/O1bQjOtTy9

name: nytimes
text: In its efforts to procure supplies to fight the coronavirus, Britain has awarded thousands of contracts worth billions of dollars. Much of that money has gone to politically connected companies, a New York Times analysis found. https://t.co/5tEO7yZQlY

name: nytimes
text: We analyzed a large segment of the spending spree ‚Äî roughly 1,200 contracts worth nearly $22 billion. About $11 billion went to firms either run by friends and associates of Conservative Party politicians, or with no experience or a history of controversy. https://t.co/MU5Js60QJi https://t.co/88RGfkAbgb

name: nytimes
text: The suppliers we spoke to denied wrongdoing, and there‚Äôs no evidence that government officials engaged in illegal conduct. But there is ample evidence of cronyism, waste and poor due diligence. https://t.co/MU5Js60QJi

name: nytimes
text: About $5 billion went to politically connected companies, including hundreds of millions to several where Britain‚Äôs PPE czar has financial interests or personal connections. A secretive ‚ÄúVIP lane‚Äù gave priority to firms with political ties. https://t.co/MU5Js60QJi https://t.co/OPPaRlMBeM

name: nytimes
text: About $6 billion went to companies with no experience in supplying medical PPE ‚Äî fashion designers, investment firms, pest controllers and jewelers. In some cases they delivered unusable goods. https://t.co/MU5Js60QJi https://t.co/1HNaPEtfT9

name: nytimes
text: More than $5 billion was awarded to companies with a history of controversy, from tax evasion and fraud to corruption and human rights abuses. https://t.co/MU5Js60QJi https://t.co/IlQU1zgA9t

name: nytimes
text: But it‚Äôs impossible to know how much the British government has spent on coronavirus supplies: Less than half of the contracts awarded in the first seven months of the year have been made public, a watchdog report found. https://t.co/MU5Js60QJi
